bug.short_desc: oAW cannot handle multiple stereotypes.

long_desc.thetext: When using model elements with more than one stereotype only the first one in the stereotype list is applied for template usage.

Duplicate of Bug#167187
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 167187 ***

bug.short_desc: Connection Timeout in UpdateManager

long_desc.thetext:
Using Eclipse 3.2.1, Build id: M20060921-0945, we are not able to install any updates or new features using the UpdateManager:
Network connection problems encountered during search. Unable to access "http://download.eclipse.org/callisto/releases". Unable to access site: "http://download.eclipse.org/callisto/releases" [Connection timed out: connect] Unable to access site: "http://download.eclipse.org/callisto/releases" [Connection timed out: connect]
This happens on every update location (e.g. Callisto, Subclipse, Eclipse Update) we have attempted although the update URL is reachable.
It doesn't seem to be a network issue, as we have also attempted to install updates using different access points to the internet, always with the same result.
Additionally, we could reproduce the problem with both JDK 1.4.2 and 1.5.

bug.short_desc: [Sync View] synchronize view: When selected multiply projects the label now says: "CVS X items"

long_desc.thetext:
Previous when i select in eclipse 3 CVS projects and sad synchronize i did see something like this in the label:
"/project1 /project2 /project3"
now i only see:
"CVS 3 items"
this is annoying because now i always have to check a few to see which one i want (i have multiply projects but some i sync as one)
So it would be nice if the 3 items where projects it would again let me see the project names instead of just "3 items".
Fixed
Verified using I20070206-0010

Created an attachment (id=69671) A screen shot of a Synchronize view
In my opinion, we will need to reconsider the solution provided by Micheal. I see Johan's point and I must say he was right about that particular case. On the other hand, the information you can see on the attachted screen shot is, in my opinion, completly useless. Maybe we can add some kind of tooltip there...
Another option is to allow the user to change the name to something meaningful and short.

or use compressing (like package names)
those names are pretty much only there if you develop eclipse plugins. All my other projects have simple mostly one word names.

attachment.desc: A screen shot of a Synchronize view

bug.short_desc: [BorderItems] BorderItemLocator has constructor with an unused parameter
SelectionTransferDragAdapter should not block draging of Folders.

long_desc.thetext:
Currently SelectionTransferDragAdapter#isDragable(ISelection) blocks dragging of source folder as LocalSelectionTransfer.
Ideally it should be the dropTarget that need to validate whether the drag is valid or not. we should not block dragging any of the ICElements in SelectionTransferDragAdapter.
I would like to get more comments on this. I can submit a patch for the same after that.

Markus and Toni, any comments?
I'd like to do something about this for 4.0
I agree that the drag adapter should allow all kinds of ICElements.
Ravi, can you take a look? Thanks.

Chris,
This has already been fixed in the latest code.
Thanks, Ravi
Janees, please verify.

bug.short_desc: compareFolders.sh failing when promoting builds

long_desc.thetext: might be a feature-not-a-bug of the new DNS policies in place for node selection between node#.eclipse.org nodes when connecting to download1.eclipse.org. To fix this, all refs to download1.eclipse.org might have to change to node1.eclipse.org instead.

If this works, everyone who has set up ssh keys to connect from emft.eclipse and emf.torolab to download1.eclipse.org will have to also set up keys for connecting to node1.eclipse.org. This can be accomplished like this:
$ ssh <yourid>@node1.eclipse.org
You shouldn't be prompted for a password, but you might get a message like one of these:
The authenticity of host 'node1.eclipse.org (206.191.52.51)' can't be established. RSA key fingerprint is 68:d8:ed:a9:c2:d8:7b:b8:90:56:0c:9e:d9:8a:17:6c. Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes Warning: Permanently added 'node1.eclipse.org' (RSA) to the list of known hosts. Warning: the RSA host key for 'node1.eclipse.org' differs from the key for the IP address '206.191.52.51' Offending key for IP in /home/nickb/.ssh/known_hosts:3 Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes
-or-
Warning: the RSA host key for 'node1.eclipse.org' differs from the key for the IP address '206.191.52.51' Offending key for IP in /home/nickb/.ssh/known_hosts:3 Matching host key in /home/nickb/.ssh/known_hosts:8 Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes
If this is the case, you'll have to delete the offending keys from the referenced file at the line number(s) specified and try again.
Fixed and tested for EMF 2.2.2M build. Should work fine for UML2/EMFT promotes too.

bug.short_desc: Correlation wizard: defualt correlation needs focus

long_desc.thetext:
In the Correlation wizard, when the user gets to the finish panel, Time is selected by default, but the user cannot just click Finish. He needs to click on the text box, first to select the text box, then Finish is enabled.
When this panel appears, that text box should have the focus, so that the user can just press Enter or click Finish.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 160876 ***
Closed as dup

bug.short_desc: Allow filtering/catories of members in structured compare

long_desc.thetext:
EMF and other technologies generate members of compilation units. The generated parts are often tagged using javadoc attributes such as "@generated". Often a minor change in the generation setting causes many structural differences, which might be combined with "user code" that was also changed.
It would be a great benefit to be able to see only user code that was changed. Generated code could be filtered, grouped differently, or deemphasized.
To achieve this behavior, JDT could provide an extension point which allows for a REGEXP to be applied to the javadoc of the member. Both sides of the comparison would have to match the expression probably.
No plans here, sorry.

bug.short_desc: [UX] Import Log Files-Need a Replace All/Append All buttons

long_desc.thetext:
When the user imports files that are currently in the workspace, they are typically importing multiple ones. For existing files there is a dialog asking whether to append or overwrite files (this is good). Since there can be multiples, users need to be able to answer this question in "Bulk". This is typically handled by having buttons for all the actions with "...All" at the end, for example, Append All, Replace All.
This is very annoying to have to respond to each of these prompts when the answer is the same for all of them.
THIS IS FOR BOTH IDE AND RCP
update target field of enhancements
[0.6pw] - Add the following buttons 'Yes to all' button. 'No to all' button. - save user selection and reuse in the same import session.
raising priority per consumer's feedback.
Resolving this as WONTFIX because it is no longer required by the consumer that requested it.

bug.short_desc: [UX] Need "No Symptom Analysis Results Found" message

long_desc.thetext: When uesrs do a symptom analysis but get no hits, they get a blank screen. We need a message either in the z-dimension, or in the results themselves that says "No results found".
Target to future. Cannot be contained in 4.4 due to limitation of resource.
This is required from AC perspective.

bug.short_desc: JDT imports exceptions mentioned in javadoc

long_desc.thetext: What are your compiler settings? Is the option in Java>Compiler>Javadoc>Process Javadoc comments (includes search and refactoring) set ? If yes, then the imports are required for the javadoc tool to work fine. In the content assist, I think you can replace the addition of import statements with the usage of fully qualified name inside the javadoc comment.
Ah, interesting. Yes, that setting is turned on (default value). Thanks for the clarification, looks like this is working as designed.
Thanks for the feedback => close as INVALID

bug.short_desc: [model] classpath decoding should use a SAX parser

are the places where a SAX parse could be used.

bug.short_desc: [modulecore] Support exclusion/inclusion filtering for virtual component wb-resource mappings

long_desc.thetext:
The virtual component framework should support excludes/includes filtering in a similar way to the JDT classpath framework.
ComponentResource currently supports a getExclusions() EList, however, this list is not referenced when retrieving member resources and support is still needed for explicit inclusion patterns as well as UI-based manipulation.
This enhancement covers:
-changes to the virtual component model -changes to code to logic that computes the virtual component members -UI support for manipulating wb-resource mappings and associated excludes/includes (would have some utility at just the API-level but really need UI support for this feature)

bug.short_desc: Replace "Project" by "Module" in messages

long_desc.thetext:
As the WST Server API doesn't imply that a Module is necessarily a Project, it would be better to adjust the messages like the "Add and remove projects..." menu entry to say "Add and remove modules..." instead.
In our case, Module have a much finer grain than projects and our users will be confused. The strings to modify are in:
/org.eclipse.wst.server.ui/serverui/org/eclipse/wst/server/ui/internal/Messages.properties
Created an attachment (id=53141) Suggested modifications of Messages.properties

Agreed, we have waffled around a bit on this. Although 'project' is incorrect, some adopters prefer it to 'module' since the server's terminology may be different. e.g. in some cases 'module' should really be 'application' or 'component' or something else.
Will investigate in 2.0 since we have no translation remaining in WTP 1.5.x.
Agreed too. The best solution then, would be to allow each type of server to specify the name ("module", "project", "application", etc.) it wants to use in messages.
*** Bug 177169 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
(From update of attachment 53141) Still looking into this, but marking the patch as obsolete since we're looking at a bigger change without using this direct patch.

bug.short_desc: xTend: Typing of add(...) operations

long_desc.thetext:
The add(...) operations on collection should be typed to the element type of the collection (which is known from the EMF meta model).
among other things, this avoids add( ..collection.. ) calls, which lead to rather strange (i.e. non-intuitive) error messages in turn.

bug.short_desc: First event isn't added to event list.

long_desc.thetext:
The first event (project container open) isn't shown in event list history.
After debugging it seems that the problem is again in services startup. The open event is sent but event history is not yet started. It is started after the open event was delivered by event service. If you start the org.eclipse.corona.client.collaboration.event, which contains the event history service, manually before opening PC, then it works properly.
Would declarative services solve it?
So far probably manual start of the plugin is the only choice.

bug.short_desc: ModuleFactory forces usage of Module instead of IModule

long_desc.thetext:
The org.eclipse.wst.server.core.internal.ModuleFactory has a getModule(id) method which returns an IModule from an ID.
As I was creating my own Module class implementing IModule, I realized that the framework was not able to find those modules after creation. It was due to a classcast exception in the above mentionned method.
The only workaround I found was to subclass the internal Module class instead.

I think that a good solution would be to change to method implentation to remove the casting on Module. In addition, it would be nice to move Module out of the internal package and to provide it as a default implementation.
Will investigate for 2.0.
Change dropped to HEAD, will release shortly. Factory uses the fact that the module id is two parts separated by ":".
Released.
Closing as fixed since M3. If this was closed in error, please reopen.

bug.short_desc: [model] IAccessRule does not say it cannot be implemented by clients

long_desc.thetext: I believe IAccessRule is not intended to be implemented by clients, but its Javadoc does not say so.
I don't think we can change this now.

Maybe you are right but from what I could see it is already impossible to implement IAccessRule (in a way that is useful), since in many places in jdt.core it is assumed that IAccessRule is implemented by ClasspathAccessRule (when reading .classpath, for instance).
Added "This interface is not intended to be implemented by clients." to Javadoc. Released for 3.4M1 in HEAD.
Verified for 3.4M1 using build I20070802-0800.

bug.short_desc: Need "cancelAll" functionality in "duplicate name collision" dialog when uploading a directory tree

long_desc.thetext:
Select a directory tree on local, choose copy. Select an empty folder on remote, choose paste. Copy the same tree again. Paste to the same location again.
RSE shows a "duplicate name collision" dialog for each and every element being uploaded. Pressing "Cancel" just cancels the current file. There is no way to get rid of the dialog, until cancel has been done for each and every element.
This is a critical problem, since it can make the whole Eclipse IDE unusable in case thouseands of resources are uploaded with collision by accident. In this case, the user's only chance to get rid of the dialog is to kill Eclipse. See also bug 162962 where this was originally detected.
Assigning to DaveD since DaveM is busy with IBM fixes for now.
Fixed. Added an option to SystemPromptDialog, which is a base API class that can be extended for simple dialogs, so clients can add a Cancel All button.
CancelAll option appears in the "Duplicate Name Collision" dialog and allows skipping all the files.
Closing.

bug.short_desc: Java perspective destroys links

long_desc.thetext:
BTW: bug is in ALL levels
The scenario: - create a file or folder link in either the navigator or C++ perspective - refactor the project to have a different name
Result: - The linked files are DELETED from their original location and become local files in your PC workspace/project
Links created in the Java perspective behave correctly when the project is renamed in the other perspectives. Likewise porjects renamed in their corresponding perspective also behave correctly.
I have labeled this "Critical" because it's destructive (it deletes the files from their original location)
I forgot to mention that the refactor is done in the Java perspective

Can you clarify what you mean by "ALL levels"... do you mean all versions of Eclipse?
I tried this in Eclipse 3.3 M3, and cannot reproduce the problem in the Package Explorer view. The Navigator view does not have a "refactor" action, but renaming the project does not delete or move the linked content. Perhaps I'm just doing something different... can you give more detailed steps? The perspective you are in doesn't matter - it's the view you are in that can affect the behaviour.
I'm wondering if this is only a problem in the C++ views?

I'm sorry, I should know better than make rash assumptions and say "all". The problem I describe appears in: 3.1.2 and 3.2. I checked further and the problem is gone in 3.2.1, 3.3M2. The problem must have been addressed in 3.2.1.
The problem occurs in the C++ perspective and our own local perspective that uses the navigator. I didn't mention our perspective since I see it in the C++ perspective.
- in a C++ project and C++ perspective add a folder that is a link - rename the C++ project in the Java perspective - Files are deleted from their remote location and end up locally on your pc
We have a package released to our customers based on Eclipse 3.1.2. Do you plan on any stablity updates of 3.1.2? If not, could you identify the fix that corrected this problem so we can build our own 3.1.2 to give to our customers?
Thanks, Dave

I still can't reproduce this in either 3.1.2 or 3.2.0. I tried Refactor > Rename in the Package Explorer view, and Rename in the Navigator view. What view is active when you perform the rename - the package explorer, navigator, or some CDT view? Can you reproduce with a simple project that is not a C++ project?

Here is a much simpler failure all from the package explorer in the java perspective/package explorer. Forget about the C perspective!
- Create a simple project (File>new>project, simple>project) - create a linked folder to an existing folder with stuff in it. The folder should be outside your workspace. - refactor>rename the simple project - note the link indicator on the folder is gone. Look closer and your see that the folder properties now point to your workspace. In windows File Explorer go look for the original location of the linked folder. You will notice that it is gone!
BTW: I have more than just Eclipse 3.1.2. I'll try a vanilla 3.1.2. I have the CDT, WTP, and the annotation package(I forget what it's called). Java 1.5

Vanilla 3.1.2 behaves the same
Vanilla 3.2 behaves the same except "simple>project" is gone. I used "General>Project" instead with the same error results.

I don't know what I was doing differently, but I can reproduce it now. Looking through the defects fixed for 3.2.1, I see this has already been addressed (as you observed).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 145733 ***

So there are no plans on any stability updates of 3.1.2? The duplicate doesn't have any patch file so it's going to be very difficult for me to find the fix in CVS. Can you help?
(In reply to comment #8) > I don't know what I was doing differently, but I can reproduce it now. Looking > through the defects fixed for 3.2.1, I see this has already been addressed (as > you observed). > *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 145733 ***

I just read the release plan for 3.1.2. The plan says that periodic stability updates for critical problems will be made. I think that this is nasty enough bug to fix in a 3.1.3. I say that because the bug actually destroys the contents of the linked folder.
If you concur, please reopen the bug as slated for 3.1.3.
Thanks

Re: Destroy. I think we are simply disagreeing on symantics. A "move" in actually "deletes" the contents from their original location and copies them to a new location. In my case I was linking to remote server and I was a bit dismayed to see that the files were gone.
Re: 3.1.3. I must be reading too much into this page: http://www.eclipse.org/eclipse/development/eclipse_maintenance_schedule_3_1_x.html
Re: fix. Thanks! I will probably end up building my own "3.1.3" with this fix.

bug.short_desc: no warning when moving/copying aj-files in package tree

long_desc.thetext:
This is a long-standing bug in the compiler - ajc does not match javac's enforcement of package structure - see bug 45190. Warnings are issued by the compiler so this cannot be addressed in AJDT.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 45190 ***

I agree that this should be discussed in the context of the AspectJ language spec and ajc's spec of a compilation unit.
I rephrase the issue in terms of an enhancement request to AJDT: no warning when moving or copying an aj-file to another package.
I moved a aj-file and the apsect from one package to anaother package. Parallel in JDT: the package statement is adjusted to the new location.
The AJDT does not, because the language spec does not require this modification. So what I really want is: refactoring "move aj-file/aspect to another package" in AJDT. Or, for the AspectJ language spec being as it is, a warning that moving aj-files might not have the expected result.
To be specific: the warning should not come from ajc as a result of the file position/package directive mismatch, but as part of the move or copy user action/dialog, thus from AJDT.
Sorry for insisting and reopening, I tried to lower the priority, but bugzilla would not have it.

I agree that AJDT should behave like JDT in this regard and update the package statement if an aspect (in a .aj file) is dragged from one package to another. This does in fact work for me. As a test I created the "TJP Example" project using the New wizard and created a new package called "package2" then dragged the GetInfo.aj file from the "tjp" package to "package2", and the package statement in GetInfo.aj correctly updated to "package2". Could you try this to see if it works for you? If so, what's different about the case where this doesn't work for you?

I think I did not move the aspect/aj-file, but I copied it, and deleted the original.
The scenario with drag and drop works for me, with two remarks (2a, 2b). Copy and Paste works differently than in JDT. See steps 6 - 8.
Details:
Starting with two aspects, Base and Derived, Derived extends Base, both in package repro, both within there own compilation unit, that is aj-file, both in the same "regular" folder.
Step 1) Create new package other with context menu New...>Package. OK
Step 2) Move Base.aj two other, by drag and drop. -> Move Wizard Dialog
2a) Expected: Refactored Source shows modified package statement Actual: ... shows original package statement.
2b) Expected from JDT behavior: Derived.aj should get a new import statement for Base. Actual: Derived is not changed.
2c) Expected from JDT behavior: Base.aj has modified package statement. Actual: OK
Step 3) Refactor > Undo: OK
Step 4) Repeat 2) with Drag and Drop of aspect Base (not aj-file). Same result as 2)
Step 5) Undo: OK
Step 6) Copy and Paste file Base.aj from package repro to package other.
Expected from JDT: (silently) modified package directive. Actual: original package directive with "repro".
Now there are two aspects with the same name, defined in two different aj-files. AJDT reports correctly "type Base already defined".
Step 7) Delete new aj-file; OK
Step 8) Repeat Step 6) with Copy and Paste of aspect (not aj-file)
Expected: same as in 6) Actual: package explorer shows Base.aj, but not aspect (as child of compilation unit.
Step 9) Delete new aj-file: OK --
Trivial Code:
Base.aj in package/folder repro --- package repro;
public abstract aspect Base { } --- Derived.aj in package/folder repro package repro;
public aspect Derived extends Base { } ---

bug.short_desc: VersionedIdentifier equals() logic in update.configurator is wrong

long_desc.thetext:
It seems the logic in update.configurator for VersionedIdentifier was a bit wonky. I had two VersionedIdentifiers that had major,minor,service,identifier,qualifier that were equals, but their versions were different, 1.0.0 & 1.0.3
The equals() check doesn't check for the version string so we get a bad return value. Also, why does this the versioned identifier have a concept of major,minor,service when it doesn't seem to be used?
If this is considered to be a low risk fix, can be think about including this for 3.2.2?

Created an attachment (id=53146) org.eclipse.update.configurator.patch
Here is a proposed patch to solve the problem.
*** Bug 162210 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Can this be looked at for 3.2.2? The comments in the duped bug appear to be correct. That is, the call to parseVersion needs to be put back into the constructor. I believe the equals method would then be correct as is and would not need the attached patch.
Adding McQ to CC as PMC representative for approval for release into 3.2 maintenance stream.
Branko, please release this into 3.2.2 and also HEAD for M4.
released in both 3.2.x and 3.3

build i1102-0010
I did a ctrl-shift-r to Open Resource and got the following exception when typing characters. It happens almost every time.
!SESSION 2006-11-02 07:06:04.187 ----------------------------------------------- eclipse.buildId=I20061102-0010 java.version=1.5.0_06 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US Framework arguments: -showlocation Command-line arguments: -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86 -debug C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Desktop\eclipse\.options -showlocation -consoleLog -console
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.jobs 4 2 2006-11-02 10:33:57.350 !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Items filtering". !STACK 0 java.util.ConcurrentModificationException at java.util.LinkedHashMap$LinkedHashIterator.nextEntry(LinkedHashMap.java:365) at java.util.LinkedHashMap$ValueIterator.next(LinkedHashMap.java:380) at org.eclipse.ui.dialogs.FilteredItemsSelectionDialog$ContentProvider.addHistoryItems(FilteredItemsSelectionDialog.java:1840) at org.eclipse.ui.dialogs.FilteredItemsSelectionDialog$FilterJob.filterContent(FilteredItemsSelectionDialog.java:1493) at org.eclipse.ui.dialogs.FilteredItemsSelectionDialog$AbstractFilterJob.internalRun(FilteredItemsSelectionDialog.java:1424) at org.eclipse.ui.dialogs.FilteredItemsSelectionDialog$AbstractFilterJob.doRun(FilteredItemsSelectionDialog.java:1386) at org.eclipse.ui.dialogs.FilteredItemsSelectionDialog$AbstractFilterJob.run(FilteredItemsSelectionDialog.java:1374) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

bug.short_desc: [actions] Organize Imports action is disabled when java file selected in synchronize view

long_desc.thetext: I added Source menu to the sync perspective. I'd like to be able to organize imports before committing an outgoing .java file. But, the entire source menu is disabled when the resource is selected in the sync view.

I'm not sure it would be a good idea to activate all object contributions in the Synchronize view. After all, the view shows changes in objects, and not the objects themselves. Moving to Plaform/Team to consider or reject.
Workarounds: - select items, Navigate > Show In > Package Explorer (Alt+Shift+W P), Source > Organize Imports - in 3.3 M3: activate a 'clean up on save' profile that organizes imports
I see your point. The file may be deleted locally. But, "Open" is shown for files which still exist locally. And that is useful.

I don't think this is unreasonable to have Organize Imports and maybe Format available from the Sync view. However, I wonder if it would be necessary given that we have the ability to perform these on save (i.e. isn't it better to have the operation on save so that the contents of the file are always right?). Thoughts?

Maybe so, but how does this request translate outside of the JDT world? What if I'm releasing HTML or some other content and its menu has also been added to the synchronize perspective?
Does it make sense for the outgoing change to be adaptable to an IResource or IFile in general, except when the resource is being deleted?

With the new model-based synchronize framework, it is the model that determines what actions appear on their elements in the sync view. Also, the Java elements that appear in the sync view do adapt to IResource. However, object contributions are turned off so Java (or models in general) would need to contribute the actions they thought made sense in the sync view using the Common Navigator action contribution mechanism.
Object contributions are turned off for several reasons. The first is the deletion case you mentioned. The other reason is because the sync view shows a filtered tree and object contributions have no accesses to the filters. Thus contributed actions would operate on more than what appears in the view.

I think it is up to JDT/UI to decide whether it makes sense to have the operations in the sync view. Personally, I think it is better to do it on save but I can see the argument for having the capability in both places. JDT already contributes actions to the sync view via the RefactoringSynchronizationActionProvider class. Any additional actions should also be contribute through there (or through a subclass if appropriate).
I guess it would make sense to offer all our actions also in the sync view.

bug.short_desc: TextFlows are always transparent

long_desc.thetext: TextFlows ignore the opaque setting. It should be fairly straight-forward to fill the background of the TextFlow (fragment by fragment) before drawing the text. This can be useful for something like highlighting, custom selection, etc.
I think for your use case, you probably need additional margin around the fragments. Filling only where the text paints is going to be too small. So maybe this could be handled by the FlowBorder.

bug.short_desc: Unable to limit the number of modules added to a server

long_desc.thetext:
We are implementing our custom modules and servers for a platform that has nothing to do with J2EE. We have a constraint that forces us to limit the number of modules deployable on a single server instance.
However, in the current state, it doesn't appear to be possible to enforce this constraint in the "Add and remove modules" wizard as it calls the canModifyModules(add, remove) method only once when creating the wizard.
It would be nice to invoke this method each time an addition or removal is done on the server instance, or each time a module is selected in the wizard panel so that we can dynamically indicate if the possible additions/removals.
Angel will be investigating whether we can make the Add/Remove wizard more dynamic by using a working copy and calling canModifyModules()/modifyModules() on every change.

This sounds like an enhancement request, to me. But, I'll mark it as P1 for now, so it won't get lost.
Tim, Angel, please further triage as you see fit.
Jerome, if this is still a big issue for you, or not, please let us know.

The major fear for this defect is introducing a call that will cause performance problems when adding a project/module. We will review this for 3.0 and determined if there is something we can enhance or provide through APIs

Could we add a "Don't show this" checkbox to its dialog settings?
Thanx, PW
yes, this is reasonable, especially since the user has been prompted once anyway.
I'll try to get to this for M4

Fixed >20061110.
I ended up moving some explanatory text into the DeleteProjectDialog and punting the extra warning dialog completely. Otherwise, it just seemed dumb to have a workspace preference titled, "Don't give me the extra reminder about undo for project content deletion."
Since we already warn the user, and give them the choice to delete content or not, it makes more sense to just add the extra warning right there, that deleting content won't be restorable via undo.

bug.short_desc: unexpected selection in Package Explorer when I turn off Focus on Active Task

long_desc.thetext: When I turn off Focus on Active Task, the package explorer shows everything in my working set and selects the item corresponding to the currently selected editor window. I often have something other than the class corresponding to the current editor window selected in the package explorer, and I expect that my selection in the package explorer window will remain unchanged even when I turn off Focus on Active Task. I have sometimes selected a specific project (or class) right before turning off Focus on Active Task specfically so I can see its entire contents but since my selection is moved elsewhere I have to find the package (or class) again. I am aware that holding down the Alt key shows you an item's children, but sometimes I want to look through a package (or class) and have it open without holding down the Alt key.

This turns out to be the opposite of what was requested on bug 159333, which is how we ended up with the current behavior. So we need to figure out what the more common use case is. I have a preference for the bug 159333 behavior, but this is largely because my workbench is set to single-click mode so that I never end up with a selection in the Package Explorer that does not correspond to the editor.
I assume that the work-around that you are using now is to double-click the element before toggling off the focused mode?
Mik, by the way that single click mode is not the default. So, by using it you probably tuning this for minority of developers.

Yes, that's correct, it is not the default and it is the minority that use it. But this isn't tuned around single-click, it's tuned around the request on bug 159333 for the reasons discussed there. If there is sufficient evidence that taking that functionality back out is the better compromise there's no problem in doing so. Please vote or comment if you prefer this functionality.

I was trying to say that bug 159333 is not the only issue related to double click setting. So, you've been unintentionally tuning to single clicks. For instance, with temporary unfiltering in package explorer, single-click selection on multiple unfiltered elements every second time fail to include those elements into context...

From my understanding, I don't think these two issues are asking for opposite functionality. I guess it depends what Jim mean by "highlighted item" in bug 159333. My problem is when I have an item selected (highlighted) in the Package Explorer and turn off Focus on Active Task and the selection in Package Explorer changes. I don't understand the conflict between scrolling to the currently selected item in the Package Explorer and keeping the currently selected item the same. I'm not totally sure I understand what bug 159333 is asking for though...

Point regarding single click taken, since I always try to aim for using the common UI settings for precisely the reason stated. Much as I dislike it because it is RSI promoting and not necessary, I have changed my workbench to double-click. However, note that I think the issue here is having the "Link with Editor" mode off, because once that's on all it takes is a single click of a Java element for it to get selected.
The main problem here was that our support for linking was a series of hacks, many particular to the Package Explorer, and lacked consistency, leading to this and other bugs related to inconsistency with other navigator views. I have fixed that up and it is now encapsulated in the new AbstractFocusViewAction. Focusing a view now causes Mylar to manage the linking, not the view's linking support. So in addition to selections not being lost, the linking is at the element level not at the file level, which we had a ways back and is much nicer when in focused mode.
Created an attachment (id=55013) mylar/context/zip
Fixed.
Reopening since this introduced a regression on the Navigator view. Thanks for pointing this out Eugene.
Fixed. FocusNavigatorAction now uses new linking policy from AbstractFocusViewAction.

bug.short_desc: ICU plug-in should export all packages

long_desc.thetext:
I20061102-0010
The ICU plug-in should export all packages. The com.ibm.icu.impl.* packages should be added to the Manifest.mf with ;x-internal:=true.
I'm not sure if this rule is intended to apply to third party plugins. For example, the org.eclipse.tomcat plugin also does not export all of its packages. Jeff, what should the rule be here?

the general rule is to export all packages and markup with x-internal/x-friends as appropriate. I don't remember why Tomcat appeared to be special/different but do remember that it was a unique special case. Superficially it seems that ICU should export the mentioned packages.
The following wiki page gives reasons why all packages should be exported: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Export-Package
Jeff - ICU4J has 5 "packages" that contain only data files (no java files). Should these be included in the list of exported packages?

those dirs look and smell like packages so should be exported. Imagine that I am hacking with an implementation of something different/related and want to use those data files. Technically I can get them using Bundle.getEntry() but these appear to be intended as "resources" and so should be discovered using the classloader. Put it another way, it doesn't hurt.

The problem is rectified in the 20070110 build with the release of ICU4J 3.4.5.20061213. Manifest is as follows: Export-Package: com.ibm.icu.lang;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.math;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.text;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.util;version="3.4.5", com.ibm.icu.impl;x-internal:=true, com.ibm.icu.impl.data;x-internal:=true, com.ibm.icu.impl.data.icudt34b;x-internal:=true, com.ibm.icu.impl.data.icudt34b.coll;x-internal:=true, com.ibm.icu.impl.data.icudt34b.rbnf;x-internal:=true, com.ibm.icu.impl.data.icudt34b.translit;x-internal:=true
ICU4J 3.6 needs to be approved to rectify the same issue in the Eclipse 3.3 stream. bug 162099 is logged for inclusion of ICU4J 3.6 in Eclipse 3.3.
verified in M20070112-1200

bug.short_desc: The State.getBundles("system.bundle") returns no matches

long_desc.thetext:
The State.getBundles("system.bundle") returns no matches. The State.getBundles("org.eclipse.osgi") works as expected.
(The State class is from the org.eclipse.osgi.service.resolver package.)
By the way, is there an API to get a "real" bundle name for the "system.bundle" ? (Just in case it is not an "org.eclispe.osgi" :-).)

(In reply to comment #1) > By the way, is there an API to get a "real" bundle name for the "system.bundle" > ? (Just in case it is not an "org.eclispe.osgi" :-).) >
Yes: BundleContext.getBundle(0).getSymbolicName();

Currently BundleContext.getBundle(0).getSymbolicName(); actually returns "system.bundle". According to the OSGi specification this is incorrect.
The system bundle should have a symbolic name that is unique for the specific framework implementation, but "system.bundle" must be recognized as an alias to this implementation-defined name. The resolver State should also perform this aliasing. The State does do some aliasing already in cases where bundles use "system.bundle" for Fragment-Host and for bundle-symbolic-name attrs on Import-Package statements. It also needs to do the aliasing for State.getBundles.
I will fix this for 3.3.

Created an attachment (id=56725) patch
This patch adds aliasing to the State for system.bundle. It also changes the system bundle Bundle object to have the correct org.eclipse.osgi symbolic name. I also had to make some changes to ensure PackageAdmin.getBundles continued to alias system.bundle correctly.
Fix released to HEAD for 3.3.

bug.short_desc: Support Microsoft Vista

long_desc.thetext:
Support Microsoft Vista - both from the workbench side and the agent controller. This would include all UI, models, communication to remote systems - basically end-to-end full product support.
All of our products are going to support Vista sometime in the future. I believe Eclipse is doing work in their next release to support Vista, however, TPTP (which is a part of the basic platform that we use in many of our products) will also need to support Vista.
In order for this to happen, most probably in the next product pickup release of TPTP, the next release of TPTP that is product consumable should be Vista compatible.

Changing Priority to P1, as demand for supporting Vista is steadily increasing, and Vista is now GM. Eclipse is seriously considering Vista Tolerance for 3.2.2, but unless TPTP follows suit, it doesn't benefit any consuming products of TPTP. If not achievable in 4.2.2, then clearly by 4.4, Vista will be critical.
Not in plan for 4.4; Moving target to future
Update target
Please add sizing

This is a top level enh to group the work required for Vista support.
Some of the work has been done in 4.4, there are remaining items moved to future. Reseting target to future to match the target of the enhancements in open state
Added bugzilla 170263 to the dependency list for full support of parsing Windows event logs on Vista.
Removed dependency on 168772
Valentina, are all of the remaining defects required before we can claim Vista support for 4.4? 168874, 170263 are targetted to 4.4, the rest are not.

TPTP offers Vista support in 4.4 release. There are a few Vista related issues which will be reviewed post 4.4; all these issues are identified not to be critical for the Vista support functionality offered in 4.4 :
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=168409 [Vista] Windows Vista, execution history timestamp is in GMT This is a JVM issue and a fix is already available in higher releases. TPTP to release a readme note describing the problem
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=168948 Not able to run AGR test with security enabled on RAC This problem is not Vista specific and will show up in any platform where large amount of data is being transferred through the RAC, with security on. We have this defect marked as critical and continue investigating the problem
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=171416 Agent Controller as a windows service on Vista can not create UI This is a limitation due to the Vista architecture. When the agent controller is installed as a service, processes that are launched by the agent controller are unable to create UI on the desktop, even if the service checkbox ("Allow service to interact with desktop") is checked.

bug.short_desc: Package Explorer does not persist expansion state

long_desc.thetext:
When restarting eclipse, The tree is completely collapsed. This is especially frustrating when only have just a few top-level treeitems displaying working sets.
This behavior differs from the Navigator View and I'm pretty sure it is a regression in the behavior of the packages view.
This was taken out for 3.0 for performance reasons, see bug 65896.
Restoring at least working set and perhaps project expansion state would help a lot.
Expanding a project can already cause the resolving of the classpath or a classpath container. All we can safely do is to restore the expansion state of the working sets. Would that make a diffence?
Yes

Actually, a working set can also consist of single files (not only projects) that would, when shown, release the classpath resolving and block the UI. Yes, I guess this could be detected before persisting the expanded state, but it feels to me that this just adding complexity and isn't really a benefit.
No plans here, setting to WON'T FIX.
Why is it that the Hierarchy View can restore its state completely on restart, but not the Package Explorer? Couldn't the same approach apply here?

I guess a main difference is that type hierarchy is an input driven view, it also has an 'not yet set' or empty state. But also restoring the type hierarchy view can be a pain. It is done in the background, but if you're really not interested in a recovered state it's slowing you down. If the type hierarchy view would be as prominent as the package explorer we might also have skipped the restore.

bug.short_desc: JET should write text files with line separators consistent with the platform preference

long_desc.thetext:
JET templates insert line separators into their output based on the platform in which the template was compiled, not the platform in which the template executes.
Thus, a JET template compiled on Windows will emit CR-LF, even on Linux.
In addition, some substitutions made by tags or embedded java may result in line seperators being insert that are inconsistent with the rest of the document.
JET should write text documents using a consistent line seperator, which should be: * the line separator specified by as the Platform default for new files * the current line separator for existing files.
Fix planned for JET 0.7.2
This is more complicate that it first seemed. Well reconsider for next release.

bug.short_desc: Warning when using jboss pool with jndi name

long_desc.thetext: Not sure if connecting from client side using JNDI without ejb is allowable in JBoss while I dont think it's about the code you've written,regards

There may be something wrong with your configuration on the server or client. Here are some suggestions for you: 1) In Jboss, your application need to depend on the service which binds the DataSource into JNDI. The DataSource is not bound into JNDI until the service jboss.jca:service=DataSourceBinding,name=(jndi-name) has been started. So that you should firstly check whether the dependent service is started. 2) After deploying the project to the server, you need a file named "jndi.properties" in the client side, which will tell the client program where to find and initialize the specified JNDI service. You can find more details in http://wiki.jboss.org/wiki/Wiki.jsp?page=DependOnDataSource Need your feedbacks. Thanks
Hi There, Any updates? Thanks.
The reports worked so it is certainly retrieving the datasource correctly out of jndi. Perhaps the connection was not closed inside birt?
We need more time to investigate this bug.
Could it be because BIRT destroy the connection? If the connection is from jboss pool, do we need BIRT release the connection back to the pool without destroying it?

BIRT does not know where connection from. So basically we will close all the connections which are opened using IConnection.open() method.It will up to jdbc driver to decide what to do when Connection.close() is called.

(In reply to comment #8) > BIRT does not know where connection from. So basically we will close all the > connections which are opened using IConnection.open() method.It will up to jdbc > driver to decide what to do when Connection.close() is called.
I agree the same component shall make the matching IConnection.open() method and close() calls. Does DtE make the open() call?

Yes DtE makes open() call and do corresponding close() calls.
We gonna need more time to investigation to this bug.
We need some extra time to go over this bug.

Hi there,
I've tried latest BIRT build (2.2.2 or 2.3) with jBoss 4.0.2 but cannot see the exception mentioned. Can you still reproduce the problem?
Thanks. Lin

bug.short_desc: Bundle-Localization Manifest Header not honored by plugin.xml editor

long_desc.thetext:
I'm seeing that if a Bundle-Localization other than the default of plugin.properties is specified in the MANIFEST.MF of a project, the plugin.xml editor no longer displays the value for any keys that were entered as attribute values.
For example, I have a project that specifies the Bundle-Localization in it's MANIFEST.MF as follows:
Bundle-Localization: OSGI-INF/l10n/bundle
I've created a a bundle.properties file in the OSGI-INF/l10n/ folder at the root of my project with the following content:
view.label=My View
Then, in the plug-in.xml for the same project I set the name attribute of one of my view extensions to %view.label. When I run the application the value for the view.label key ("My View") is automatically retrieved and displayed in the app. However, if I open the plugin.xml editor "My View" does not appear, but rather "%view.label".
Note that if I had not changed the location of the Bundle-Localization it would have defaulted to plugin.properties in the root of my project. In this situation the plugin.xml editor displays the key value correctly, and "My View" would appear next to the view extension.
So, whatever mechanism does the lookup is working correctly in the application, but the plugin.xml editor doesn't appear to do it's lookup based on Bundle-Localization.
Created an attachment (id=53162) View of plugin.xml editor when using OSGI-INF/l10n/bundle.properties
Created an attachment (id=53164) Key value is correctly applied to the application view label.
Created an attachment (id=53165) View of plugin.xml editor when using plugin.properties

Going through and fixing all the Bundle-Localization bugs.
Updated org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.bundle.BundlePluginModelBase v1.18 and org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.text.plugin.PluginModelBase v1.4. Should be available in 3.3M5
Note: PDE searches for the properties file when the editor is opened. Therefore, if you change/add a Bundle-Localization header, you must reopen the editor to refresh the properties search. Since this is not unique to the Bundle-Localization header and instead with the way PDE editors search properties files, it should be considered a different bug.

attachment.desc: View of plugin.xml editor when using OSGI-INF/l10n/bundle.properties
Key value is correctly applied to the application view label.
View of plugin.xml editor when using plugin.properties

bug.short_desc: Can not write to servlet output stream when BIRT is used in Tiles

long_desc.thetext:
Hi, Ryan Barker:
What exception happened? Can you tell me the content of the exception?
When outputing HTML, we use java.io.OutputStreamWriter to write the stream. When outputing PDF, we use java.io.BufferedOutputStream to write the stream.
An OutputStream can be opened and written by muti-OutputStreamWriter or muti-BufferedOutputStream. Of cause the thread safe must be implemented.
Is the stream of "response.getOutputSteam()" thread safe? It will cause an indeterminate result if two writers are writing a same stream in the same time.
Thanks.

(In reply to comment #1) > Hi, Ryan Barker: > > What exception happened? Can you tell me the content of the exception? > > When outputing HTML, we use java.io.OutputStreamWriter to write the stream. > When outputing PDF, we use java.io.BufferedOutputStream to write the stream. > > An OutputStream can be opened and written by muti-OutputStreamWriter or > muti-BufferedOutputStream. Of cause the thread safe must be implemented. > > Is the stream of "response.getOutputSteam()" thread safe? It will cause an > indeterminate result if two writers are writing a same stream in the same time. > > Thanks. >
response.getOutputSteam() throws an exception due to the stream already being open by the parent servlet. The only available option is response.getWriter(). Its very similar to this: http://forum.java.sun.com/thread.jspa?threadID=676451&messageID=3948831
your workaround is the suggested solution in this case.

bug.short_desc: SDB edit overview page consumes lots of memory

long_desc.thetext:
1) Enable the Eclipse heap status 2) Import a large symptom catalog 3) gc a few times
After the catalog has been imported, the editor is opened showing the overview page. Display of the overview page should not consume a lot of memory. However, it does. The memory should only be used after the user clicks on the details tab.
Heap usage with a large catalog (18,000 defns):
Editor open to overview page: 107 MB Close editor : 15 MB
Since most users are importing the catalog for analysis not editing, the editor is holding precious memory that can be used for analysis, causing the analysis to run more slowly.

The performance of Log Analysis has been raised as an issue by an IBM customer.
Please consider this defect for inclusion in the next TPTP fix pack.
Alex, please take a look. I would say this is a post 4.3 'defect'.

There are two issues here: one is whether the "Open sdb in editor" check box should be checked in the Import sdb wizard by default and the second is that the symptom 2.0 editor is loading the resource upfront instead of doing a lazy loading when the details page is first selected. The user can avoid loading the imported sdb in the editor by unchecking the check box if he doesn't want to edit or display the symptom definitions and just use the sdb for log analysis.

Deferring this to 4.4 because there is a workaround that can be added to the 4.3 readme:
When importing a symptom database for analysis, uncheck the "Open in editor" check box in the import dialog.
Alex, please open a defect to add this to the readme.
I set the priority to P1 so it has high priority to fix in 4.4.
Readme defect https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=163272 opened.
Fixed.
Verified. Closing.

bug.short_desc: FTP Only can not delete first subfolder

long_desc.thetext:
When selecting more than one file/directory delete fails if the multiselect contains two or more directories.
connect to a FTP Only site
create a folder aaa create a folder bbb
select aaa and bbb and try to use delete from context menu
after progess dialog the files/directories selected for deletion are still there
-----------Enter bugs above this line-----------
----------- Linux 64 bit configuration ----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 3 installation : eclipse-platform-3.2 (3.2.0.v20060603) actually this is a eclipse project export of our product based on Eclipse 3.2 that contains RSE RSE install : SDK download RSE I20061102-1200 java.runtime : java version "1.5.0_06" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_06-b05) Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 1.5.0_06-b05, mixed mode) os.name: : Linux janus 2.6.15-27-amd64-generic #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Sep 16 01:50:50 UTC 2006 x86_64 GNU/Linux ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Unix-ssh targetos : Kubuntu Linux Dapper (6.06) targetuname : Linux janus 2.6.15-27-amd64-generic #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Sep 16 01:50:50 UTC 2006 x86_64 GNU/Linux ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Windows dstore targetos : Microsoft Windows XP [Version 5.1.2600] targetvm : java version "1.5.0_06" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_06-b05) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_06-b05, mixed mode, sharing) ------------------------------------------------
correction the problem is triggered if one element of the selection (which could be the only one) is the first subfolder in the folder. (I changed the summary)
Javier please look at this

FTP can not delete non empty folders. It could be the reason why it's failing to delete if you try to delete a folder containing something.
Creating two empty folders, aaa and bbb (at the same level) and deleting them works fine for me.

In case the folder is not empty, can you cast an error message (via SystemMessageException), e.g. "Delete failed - folder not empty" ?
That would certainly avoid some confusion.

I think this message should be raised in the UI layer rather than in the FTP engine. This way all subsystems failing to delete would have consistent error messages.
A suitable place could be: SystemView.doDelete(IProgressMonitor) line: 4361
I would also suggest monitoring at this level the deletion of resources rather than leaving it up to the subsystem engines (and it can be extended to all other monitorable/cancellable actions)

I have fixed the issue, but now when deleting multiple files/folders and one of them fails (throwing a RemoteFolderNotEmptyException), the next files/folders are not attempted to be deleted by the higher layers. The exception is catched too high in the architecture:

Opened bug 163565 (Multiple files are not deleted when one of them fails to be deleted)
Fixed on I20061107-0700. Exception an exception is thrown when attempting to delete an empty folder.

Can delete a single empty folder. OK Can delete multiple empty folders. OK Receive warning when deleting non-empty folders. OK Receive warning when deleting a mix of empty & non-empty folders. Empty folders prior to the warning are deleted. Empty folders after the non-empty folder are not deleted. OK (this is the expected behavior, but I have reservations about it.)
I find an operation that only partially completes to be strange. Would it be possible to continue to delete empty folders to complete the operation and place a message in the log for each non-empty folder indicating that it could not be deleted? It may be possible to throw an exception at the end saying that some folders could not be deleted.
The folders were deleted in the order they are listed in the confirmation dialog. However these folders are listed in the confirmation dialog in reverse order from their listing in the RSE tree. I find this odd. It appears to be a bug in the UI as it happens for all file services.

I'm not sure if the fix is really a fix, as the user now needs to clean the affected folder himself. If the folder is a nested hierarchy like a Java source folder that will become very painful if the user has to go and delete all the folders in the hierarchy manually (one at a time)
would it be possible to check if the selected folders are non empty before trying to delete? In that case the UI could ask the user what to do (don't delete or delete all contents). I also think that at the UI level we should always be able to delete folders (empty or not). One way to accomplish that in the subsystem that can't do it directly (ftp) is that the subsystem first does a scan, finds all leaves, deletes them and then goes to the next level.

bug.short_desc: Have a flag that FORCES clean (re)generation of code.

long_desc.thetext:
It is slowly but definitely getting on my nerves, that I constantly have compile errors after code regerating (be it the emf-.edit(or)-code or in the .diagram code. Obviously these errors are caused by failed attempts to merge the newly generated code with the already existing code (even though I haven't any modified or non-generated code,yet!). After deleting the buggy projects and another re-generation round things are usually back to nomal.
At least for the phase where one hasn't customized anything, yet, it would be VERY helpful and timesaving to have a flag that simple FORCES all existing code to be overwritten WITHOUT trying to merge anything (or delete the old code before the regeneration).
Michael
I've submitted https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=175282 so if the code merger could be a bit more agressive it won't be such a pain. For now you may just remove the projects.

bug.short_desc: After a period of not using the Windows dstore connectio gets unusable

long_desc.thetext:
After a period of not using the Windows dstore connection get stale and thus unusable. The connection still shows as connected, but trying to expand MyHome or Drives get "Pending..." for a long time (minutes) and when they finally return "Folder '.' not found" or "Empty List"
If this happens in create filter browse it locks up the complete UI for minutes.
Even Disconnect/Connect does not revive the connection. A restart of the local Linux client application however works. No need to restart the rseserver deamon on Windows.
I set it to critical, as Disconnect/Connect does not remedy the problem.
maybe connected systems should send keepalive (like every minute) as long as the user does not manually disconnect.

Hm. We had a similar problem in bug 142974.
That bug was verified, so I wonder if the behavior described here is reproducable. In fact, dstore does send keepalives, so I wonder what's going on here. Apparently, the dstore server died, but why did the client not react to the missing keepalives?
Did you see any error output on the dstore server's shell? Did you see anything in the PDE error log?
Assigning to DaveM, but I guess he'll need more information to look into this.

Actually, I've been running a Linux -> Windows-dstore connection myself for 2 days uptime now, so it looks like this is not reproducable all the time.
Reading again, I see that the dstore daemon should be healthy, but the client is getting stuck somehow. Should check logs on the client.
Decreasing severity from critical to major, since only one connection is affected but the rest of Eclipse is still healthy; so the user can quit & restart Eclipse at a time he wants to which brings the connection in order again.
I just tried this, leaving the windows dstore connection for two hours but didn't hit any problems. This was done on a windows client rather than a linux one - does that make a difference for you?
Decreasing severity since this is reproducable very rarely only, and the user has a chance to fix it (quit and restart client).
Marking this as works for me since I can't reproduce it and I haven't heard back on this for a while.

bug.short_desc: Have a one-click regenerate-all option.

long_desc.thetext:
During the phase where one still fiddles with the look-and-feel of an application (i.e. while one has no hand-modified or non-generated code, yet) I find it most tedious that I have to issue two context-menu commands and click away at least three dialogs each time until the model generator is regenerated and the diagram code is rebuilt, so that I can test the modified code.
* right-click .gmfmap file and select "Create generator model" * 1st dialog: OK the .gmfgen file name * 2nd dialog: click "No" on the buggy question re. stale .ecore model * 3rd dialog: OK on the Generator Model Options (move those into the preferences!) * next one has to right-click the gmfgen file and has to select "create diagram code"
PLEASE provide an option to do all this in a single shot!
Michael
PS.: Ideally even including the launch of the newly generated plugins :-)

Oops - sorry. That should been using severity "enhancement".
Michael
*** Bug 160840 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I would like to request that such a feature include the option to compare and merge the outcome of the transformation from gmfmap to gmfgen with its previous version before proceeding to generate the diagram code.

bug.short_desc: Cascading parameter dialog - Changing from multiple to single dataset does not work

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to reproduce -
- Create a new cascading parameter group - Select multiple dataset - define parameter country and associate it with datasetCountry - define parameter state and associate with datasetSate
Now try to change from multiple dataset to single dataset. The second dataset still shows up and also the report design file is wrong. The single dataset should be saved ast he cascading parameter group level.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 163271 ***

bug.short_desc: Cascading parameter dialog - Changing from multiple to single dataset does not work

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to reproduce -
- Create a new cascading parameter group - Select multiple dataset - define parameter country and associate it with datasetCountry - define parameter state and associate with datasetSate
Now try to change from multiple dataset to single dataset. The second dataset still shows up and also the report design file is wrong. The single dataset should be saved ast he cascading parameter group level.

I think GUI doesn?t need to clear the property for we treat single / multiple data sets as 2 different concepts. Please see attached email. This means if the engine run a cascading parameter with the ?<property name="dataSetMode">single</property>?, it should treat it as single data set parameter and ignore the data sets, which depends on the parameter.
*** Bug 163270 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Fixed.
If a cascading parameter group is single dataset mode, the datasets defined on the paramters in the group are all ignored, and only the dataset defined on the group are used.
To verify: 1. create a report, create several different datasets. 2. create a cascading parameter group, set dataset mode to multiple. 3. add several parameters and specify defferent datasets for them. 4. save. 5. modify the xml souce file : a. change dataset model of group to single. b. specify dataset for the group. 6. Run the report, check if the choices of parameters are from the dataset of group. If so, the behavior is correct.

bug.short_desc: [FieldAssist] - ControlDecoration should not require FieldDecoration in constructor

At present, one needs to give it some dummy FieldDecoration.

I know that there's documentation missing at least ToolTipHelper#createTooltip() should state that it's valid to return null if no tooltip has to be displayed but I'm ran out of time today. There's also an issue when the parent shell is put into background while the tooltip is shown.
Created an attachment (id=53410) Patch representing the previous changes

I have issues : 1) use of Timer class. Is there a reason we can't just use Display.timerExec and forgo the async call? 2) statically referring to the currently opened tooltip (assumed to be a singleton) when there is no synchronization on the open/dispose methods. All kinds of badness could happen here. 3) use of Display filters. These are dangerous things that should be avoided at all costs. Are they absolutely necessary? 4) I worry that too much of the implementation for Tooltip isn't final. This relates more to the previous two issues which make the solution brittle and dangerous. For instance, a Tooltip implementation with broken dispose() would leave an increasing number of display filters, shells, and threads (in the Timer) in the system. 5) There is one abstract Tooltip class, another abstract helper, and yet another support class. Can this be condensed to one access point?

(In reply to comment #15) > I have issues : > 1) use of Timer class. Is there a reason we can't just use Display.timerExec > and forgo the async call?
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=83200#c32
Well yes we could ( and I did in the up coming version ;-). The draw back is that we cann't cancle runnables scheduled with timerExec but I wasn't also really happy with the Timer implementation so its gone.
> 2) statically referring to the currently opened tooltip (assumed to be a > singleton) when there is no synchronization on the open/dispose methods. All > kinds of badness could happen here.
Accepted and should be no problem any more because of using Display.timerExec() so we are in the same thread all day long. Right?
> 3) use of Display filters. These are dangerous things that should be avoided > at all costs. Are they absolutely necessary?
How would you propose to get informed when the mouse leaves the current tooltip, I really really would love to not use the Display-Filters but I can't see another possibility to get informed about mouse leaving events?
> 4) I worry that too much of the implementation for Tooltip isn't final. This > relates more to the previous two issues which make the solution brittle and > dangerous. For instance, a Tooltip implementation with broken dispose() would > leave an increasing number of display filters, shells, and threads (in the > Timer) in the system.
I'll upload a new version in a few minutes where people are not able to break dipose() any more.
> 5) There is one abstract Tooltip class, another abstract helper, and yet > another support class. Can this be condensed to one access point?
If now done the following: - ToolTipPart => Hides ToolTip completely from the User who is not even able any more to create an instance from it - ToolTip => reduced the visibility to package - ToolTipSupport => package visible and used in conjuction with LabelProviders which might not make sense for other controls
This means there's only one public access point namely ToolTipPart.

Created an attachment (id=53482) New public interface to implement tooltip support
Created an attachment (id=53483) Rewritten Support for Viewers
Created an attachment (id=53484) Snippet to reflect changes

I've looked at the code a bit (haven't dug too deep yet) but many of the issues I had have been addressed. I tried playing around with the snippet and came across some issues that may or may not be legitimate.
1) on OS X the tooltip shell background color is the default grey gradient that normal shells have. Should these things look like standard tooltips without undo effort?
2) I added a tree to the example snippet and tried to interact with it when the tip appeared. The tip would always disappear if I either had to move to get into it or used the mouse button. Should it be possible to interact with these shells in any way? If not, that should be documented somehow.

bug.short_desc: [Field Assist] - Remove FieldDecoration from use in registry

long_desc.thetext:
Recognizing that FieldDecoration is API and required by DecoratedField, lets look at its use for the registry.
In the past it made sense to have standardized icon+message pairings (e.g. ! "Content Assist is Available"), with these added as FieldDecorations to the registry. But there are no standard messages now, they are all computed. Thus all we need is a registry of icons, not FieldDecorations.
Another solution would be a factory class that sets the appropriate icon, or icon and message, eg.
DecorationFactory.default().setError(ControlDecoration) DecorationFactory.default().setWarning(ControlDecoration)
If ever say we wanted errors and warnings say to at different locations, this could be easily encoded in the factory methods (at present this cannot be expressed because the registry holds FieldDecorations which only know image+message).

this is covered in bug 163345. Note that we couldn't remove the use of decorations from the registry, but would deprecate FieldDecoration and the registry itself.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 163345 ***

bug.short_desc: [Field Assist] - ControlDecoration should not expose FieldDecoration

long_desc.thetext:
Recognizing that FieldDecoration is API and required by DecoratedField, lets look at its use with ControlDecoration.
ControlDecoration now takes a single FieldDecoration from which it pulls the icon and message. Since it only has a single FieldDecoration, its not clear why we still require this separate class (DecoratedField had several so this may just be a hold over).
Instead, we could just have: void setImage(Image) void setMessage(String) methods on ControlDecoration. This way too, if the message string is visible (say a via a hover) and the client updates the message string via ControlDecoration.setMessage(), it can know to update the that hover text.
This probably means we can get rid of ControlDecoration.showHoverText(String).

this was fixed via bug #163461, available in I20061107. (All of your bugs on this topic lingered in the ui-inbox while I opened duplicates as I was fixing them...) thanks for opening them, I just didn't see them.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 163461 ***

bug.short_desc: [Field Assist] - Is FieldDecoration still required?

long_desc.thetext: FieldDecoration is API and required by DecoratedField, but if we depricate DecoratedField, then we no longer require FieldDecoration if we can eliminate its use: - as API in ControlDecoration - for use in the registry

See bug #163345, it contains the exhaustive list of what would be deprecated if DecoratedField is deprecated. Note that none of these classes would disappear, but they could all be marked deprecated.

bug.short_desc: FieldEditorPreferencePage needs a default constructor

long_desc.thetext:
The Field Editors help topic at http://127.0.0.1:12345/help/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/preferences_prefs_fieldeditors.htm?
does not mention that classes that extend FieldEditorPreferencePage must provide a default constructor.
If a program attempts to add a class to a plugin project that extends FieldEditorPreferencePage, and checks the box to generate constructors from the base class, the new file has three constructors, but no default constructor. The resulting preference page cannot be instantiated by the UI.
The documentation should be enhanced to mention that extending classes must provide a default constructor, and that constructor must invoke super(int) constructor.

Field editors help topic.
Bottom of the page:
The FieldEditorPreferencePage will use a grid layout with one column as the default layout for field editor widgets. For special layout requirements, you can override the createContents method.
Since the class has private fieldEditorParent and has no set method for this field, I don't think that this class can use anything other than the layout wired in by createContents. Yet another example of lost re-use because of private fields.

All classes referred to by a schema need to have default constructors.
We should however add a default constructor for FieldEditorPreferencePage in order to support the preferencePages extension point.
Added constructor for build >20070329
VERIFIED in I20070430-0010

bug.short_desc: [EditorMgmt] "Operation Warning" dialog on project delete leads to rule violation

long_desc.thetext:
This is a new bug in 3.3, as of I20061102-0010 or possibly earlier; it works in 3.2.1. The quick summary is that it looks like a change in the UI for project deletion is causing some operations to happen out of order; a Save All is being triggered during project deletion.
TO REPRO:
Launch Eclipse in a new workspace. Close the 'Welcome' page. Create a new plug-in project, named "foo". Click Next to go to the second wizard page, uncheck both Plug-in Options, and then hit "Finish" to accept all other defaults. Click "YES" to go to Plug-in Perspective.
In the manifest editor, in the Dependencies tab, add org.eclipse.core.resources as a dependency. Save. In the Extensions tab, click Add... and add org.eclipse.core.resources.builders. Click Finish.
Right-click the new extension and click New... to add "builder". Right-click the "builder" element and click New... to add "run". Click the "class" link and type IPB in the Name field. Click Finish. Do *NOT* save.
In package explorer, right-click the "foo" project, and click Delete. In the confirmation dialog, select "Also delete contents..." and click YES.
In 3.2.1, the project is deleted and we're done.
But not in 3.3 I20061102-0010. There, an "Operation Warning" dialog appears, saying what will happen if all contents are deleted. Click YES.
A Save Resource dialog now appears, asking whether to save changes to 'foo'; again click YES.
An "Error" dialog now appears, with text "Save All Failed:Attempted to beginRule: R/, does not match outer scope rule: P/foo". Also, a warning and an error are both added to the error log, each with message "Save All Failed", from plug-in org.eclipse.ui.
Dismissing the "Error" dialog leaves the "Save Resource" dialog still present. Clicking YES again does dismiss it, and the project is apparently deleted.
The error does not have a stack trace available. The stack trace of the warning is:

bug.short_desc: Open/Activate task dialogs should pickup current selection

long_desc.thetext: Open/Activate task dialogs should pickup current selection. So, you could have search criteria filled in automatically.
Created an attachment (id=53177) Simple patch to pickup selection from selection service

Tried to apply, but it looks like the current patch fills in the text without triggering the filtering. You may have done this to preserve the nice feature of having the recent matches pop up, but it breaks the simple model of the filter aleays being the right thing, and means that the user needs to type over the text to figure out what's going on.
One concern I have is if it will be common for people to get the wrong text selection in there (e.g. a Java element). But this is a nice work-around to the cases where we don't have hyperlinking. and perhaps it's OK if the pre-filled filter text is selected by default so that the user can easily type over it.
Willian: what are your thoughts on this?
I wonder if Ctrl+Shift+F11 should just open the task if the selected ID is in the list, and if not just pop up the usual dialog? Eugene: I'm guessing that would address your most common use case?

Created an attachment (id=53199) Revised patch
The setText() must be made after the addModifyListener() to trigger the initial filtering.
The revised patch works the way you expected.
There is one little issue there yet, which is if you have more than one line selected in a text editor, for example, the initial selection will contain "squares" in the middle of text. In this case, I think would be better to analyze the text and get only the first line, Eugene.
Regarding your question, Mik, I don't know for sure if it would be usefull for me, particularly. This should work only for ITextSelections, which I think == subclasses of TextEditor, in most cases.
I don't known exactly Eugene's use case, but assuming it is for selecting task ids inside text, I presume this string would be inside a comment block, so wouldn't hyperlinking work?
Created an attachment (id=53200) mylar/context/zip

Created an attachment (id=53211) Added text preselection and detection of multiline selection
I also fixed some weirdness in the matching. It is probably due to recent Mik's changes in QueryHit class. So, it need to match on hit.getIdLabel().
I wonder if ITask should also have getIdLabel() method
Created an attachment (id=53212) mylar/context/zip

Yes, at some point hyperlinking should work for this. For now it seems reasonable to popualte with the selection, but let's monitor carefully whether users find that this is causing more bogus populations than intentional populations. The good thing is that with the fixes it is pretty unobtrusive since you can just start typing right away.
Patch applied. Willian, your patch is also included in the IP Log, but I only applied Eugene's since it seemed to contain it.

(In reply to comment #3) > I don't known exactly Eugene's use case, but assuming it is for selecting task > ids inside text, I presume this string would be inside a comment block, so > wouldn't hyperlinking work?
My original idea as to use it in CVS/SVN history comments area. But they doesn't seem have support for selection service. Heh, I guess I'll have to submit some more patches there as well... ;-)
That's the good thing about this approach: it'll be easier to convince Platform and others to participate in the selection service than it is for them to add hyperlink detectors.

(In reply to comment #10) > That's the good thing about this approach: it'll be easier to convince Platform > and others to participate in the selection service than it is for them to add > hyperlink detectors.
I know! They can't refuse implementation of their own API. :-)

Internet Explorer does not support XHTML files. I cannot find the official words from Microsoft. But, tests by W3C (http://www.w3.org/People/mimasa/test/xhtml/media-types/results) show that IE recognizes XHTML files with "text/html" content type as HTML files.
I found the following XHTML files in Eclipse 3.2 docs: eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\gettingStarted\qs-02d.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\gettingStarted\qs-24a.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\gettingStarted\qs-34a.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\gettingStarted\qs-34b.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\gettingStarted\qs-34c.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\tasks\help.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\tasks\tasks-51.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\tasks\tasks-53.xhtml eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\tasks\tasks-57.xhtml
The first question is whether we should produce doc files in XHTML at all.
The second issue I noticed, the exceptions seen by the testers were related to the Java level. When I launch Eclipse with IBM Java 1.4.2_10, those XHTML pages display okay. However, when I launch Eclipse with IBM Java 1.5.0, exceptions are thrown for those XHTML pages. (See attached .log file.)
Note: no exceptions are thrown for English docs when Eclipse is launched with IBM Java 1.5.0 because there are no UTF-8 chars in the files.
Yes, we are using the NL pack from IES for Eclipse 3.2.1.
