bug.short_desc: Machines list in parallel launch configuation is empty

long_desc.thetext: This problem happens if the PTP runtime has not started before opening an existing or new parallel launch configuration. When the run configuration is opened, the PTP runtime is (correctly) started by a call to refreshRuntimeSystems(). However, it appears that this is happening too late for the machines list in the parallel tab to be populated correctly, since it is empty.
Is this supposed to be populated with the name that appears in Machine->Node Info View, not Machine0?
No, Machine0 is probably correct. It should be whatever machines are known by the model. The only other drop down like this is on the menu bar of the machines view.

The events causing the problem are (starting from ParallelTab.createControl):
1. The parallel tab calls ModelManager.refreshRuntimeSystems 2. ModelManager.refreshRuntimeSystems starts up the Proxy Client Event Thread - Proxy Client Event Thread receives the EVENT_RUNTIME_CONNECTED and EVENT_RUNTIME_OK events 3. ModelManager.refreshRuntimeSystems calls initiateDiscovery and finishes 4. ParallelTab calls universe.getSortedMachines while 5. The Proxy Client Event Thread waits for an event, gets EVENT_RUNTIME_NODEATTR, and updates the model.
The bug occurs when 4 occurs before 5 completes (a race).
Fix was done by waiting in ModelManager.refreshRuntimeSystems until the machines list is updated via EVENT_RUNTIME_NODEATTR. This is a bit of a hack as Eclipse will hang if machines list comes back empty.
Need to revisit in version 2.0

There is another problem which maybe associated with this one.
Assuming the Preference: PTP > OpenRTE > "Launch ORTE server manually" is unchecked, and the ORTE|PTP proexy server file is set correctly, the orted can not always be guaranteed to start.
Here is the reason: THe PTPUIPlugin::refreshRuntimeSystem() is only called either when preference is changed or the ParallelTab or AbstractParallelSetView becomes visible.
Case (NOT work): User start Eclipse with C/C++ perspective (assuming no AbstracParallelSetView visible), at this time, Eclipse won't start the orted automatically,i.e., PTPUIPlugin::refreshRuntimeSystem() is not called, so the orted is not started. Then user presses Ctrl+F11 to run a preconfigured program, PTP will popup a launch error dialog. The error is caused when Eclipse waiting for the universe to populate (which is never populated, since PTPUIPlugin::refreshRuntimeSystem() is never called before this step).

One solution may be to check if the orted is started each time starting a launch (by the launch delegate), if not, then call PTPUIPlugin::refreshRuntimeSystem() to start?
Sorry if this is not related to the original defect. I could not find a right way to report a new defect for PTP since the Eclipse bugzilla seems un-friendly. :-(

Comments 4 & 5 refer to a known problem, that was thought to be resolved. I'm not sure which bug number.
Are you using the latest 1.1 release? If so, then I need to have another look at this.
PTP 2.0 will be handling this in a completely different way, but we need to get this problem resolved.
Regards, Randy

I use 1.1 RC4, with Eclipse 3.2.2 + CDT 3.1.2, and openmpi-1.2rc2.
BTW, what's the way 2.0 will handle this?

PTP 2.0 will be using resource managers more heavily. You will configure and startup a set of resource managers. These will be responsible for launching jobs. Resource managers will be configured based on the type of proxy they run, what cluster on which they ultimately run, and what the underlying actual resource manager is. For example, there will be separate resource managers for ORTE, and MPICH. Resource managers for LSF and Moab will be available for 2.0. We hope that others can contribute their own resource managers, via the extension point mechanism.
You may have more than one resource manager of a given type running at the same time. You could have two LSF resource managers running at the same time, one using a cluster at Los Alamos, the other using a cluster at a university.
Any resource managers that have been started when PTP is shutdown will be restarted automatically when PTP starts running. This happens when any PTP window is brought up, or when a PTP-based launch configuration is executed.
If for some reason the specific resource manager associated with a particular launch configuration is not in an acceptable state, either has not been started, or in an error sate, then the launch configuration will fail.
Any questions?
Randy

Created an attachment (id=61165) Fixe the java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException when launch preference set to prompt
Because of race condition, the universe could still be null when setting the Preference Run/Debug>Perspectives>Parallel Application to 'prompt'.
The patch add check and will wait until universe popup or user cancelled.

Randy, thanks for your explaination. Hope I can get 2.0 soon.
About #9, it is a patch for the race condition which happened when setting the launch preference to 'prompt' instead of 'always'. see greg's comments at: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/ptp-user/msg00071.html
Basically, the java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException is caused by NullPointerException in ModelManager::waitForPopulatedUniverse.

bug.short_desc: support for 'archive' scheme in the WorkspaceSynchronizer.getFile

long_desc.thetext:
Please note, I have tried using a specialization of a URIConverter that correctly resolves the archive scheme. It does not help either: normalizing the 'archive' URI into a 'file' URI does the trick for resolving the files but crashes everything else that requires an exact URI.
Thanks for your help in advance!

I'm not very familiar with the "archive" scheme, but doesn't it mean that the the URI identifies a file within an archive file? In that case, there is no mapping to IFile, is there? The only IFile that would be recognized by the workspace is the archive, itself, which isn't what the URI identifies.

You are right: the archive URI identifies a zip entry inside the archive.
For example when the file is c:/workspace/project/test.bpm and the zip-entry inside is 'model.bpmn_diagram' the URI is: archive:file:/c:/workspace/project/test.bpm!model.bpmn_diagram This archive scheme is supported by EMF: org.eclipse.emf.common.util.SCHEME_ARCHIVE And the file happens to be inside a workspace project.
So there is no bi-directional mapping between an IFile and such a URI.
However, in the context of how GMF uses this method it it does make sense to return the IFile; adding this patch enables us to use a single file to store multiple EMF-Resource. In our case the graphical model and the domain model of the diagram as well as other arbitrary files in fact.
Maybe GMF should not be calling WorkspaceSynchronizer.getFile(Resource) in the first place?
Here is the situation. It is used by most GMF commands to get the "affectedFiles": http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/org.eclipse.gmf/plugins/org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.commands.core/src/org/eclipse/gmf/runtime/emf/commands/core/command/AbstractTransactionalCommand.java?rev=1.5&cvsroot=Technology_Project&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup in the method "getWorkspaceFiles()"
For example: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/org.eclipse.gmf/plugins/org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.properties/src/org/eclipse/gmf/runtime/diagram/ui/properties/sections/AbstractModelerPropertySection.java?rev=HEAD&cvsroot=Technology_Project&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup is called when there the font is changed in the properties of a GMF diagram.
I agree with you that if the purpose of getFile is to return the file that is equivalent to the EMF-Resource then we must return null. However, it looks like the way this method is used tends to expect the Resource to be 'adapted' into a File.
Should we file a bug against GMF and ask them to not rely on this method? Not using IFile might also fix 133038 in the same shot.
My apologies if this comment really should be happening inside the GMF bugzilla. I am lucky you are contributing on both!
Thanks for your help.
Moving to 1.2 release to consider an addition to the WorkspaceSynchronizer API that would return the IFile representing the archive containing a Resource. How GMF might use it is another matter.

bug.short_desc: Browser widget on Mac OS X won't display PDF file

long_desc.thetext: You shouldn't need to have Adobe Reader installed to view PDFs on a Mac. Safari shows PDFs natively. Could you try running it on a mac without Adobe Reader installed?

(In reply to comment #1) > You shouldn't need to have Adobe Reader installed to view PDFs on a Mac. Safari > shows PDFs natively. Could you try running it on a mac without Adobe Reader > installed? >
Unfortunately, I only have the one Mac. I'd be happy to uninstall the Adobe plugin from Safari to try and gain a little more insight into the issue. If that works, I'd definitely consider this a bug. And even if it works, I cannot prevent users from having the Adobe Reader plugin installed>

(In reply to comment #2) > (In reply to comment #1) > > You shouldn't need to have Adobe Reader installed to view PDFs on a Mac. Safari > > shows PDFs natively. Could you try running it on a mac without Adobe Reader > > installed? > > > > Unfortunately, I only have the one Mac. I'd be happy to uninstall the Adobe > plugin from Safari to try and gain a little more insight into the issue. If > that works, I'd definitely consider this a bug. And even if it works, I cannot > prevent users from having the Adobe Reader plugin installed> >
I was reading Safari's help docs, and they state, "f you use a third-party PDF plug-in for Safari, it will block Safari's built-in PDF support." So I then cam across this article, http://www.macfixit.com/article.php?story=20060831091053988, which describes how to disable the Adobe Reader plugin. Once I disabled the plugin, problem went away. From the help docs, it seems that this is just the way Safari works. It should also be noted that you need to be an admin user to disable the Adobe plugin.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

Have you modified the data source in your rptdesign files? If so these data source would be localized and its connection to origianl rptlibrary will be cut.
Thanks. Lin

It's old issue. You should be explicit to refresh library: right click report design and choose 'refresh library' , then you can get new value of data source in library. We can refresh library in background, but it is dangerous. so now the behavior is you should be explicit to refresh library. Maybe it is not convenient, we will consider to do enhancement. Thanks!

bug.short_desc: [Smoke]Error occurs when finish creating a SQL Stored Procedure Query Data Set

long_desc.thetext: Description: [Smoke]Error occurs when finish creating a SQL Stored Procedure Query Data Set Steps to reproduce: 1, New a data source (URL:jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://spmdb/gui) 2, Add a data set.Select data set type "SQL Stored Procedure Query". 3, Edit this data set "{call counterInT1(?)} " 4, Change the dataset parameter's direction to 'Output' 5, Click 'OK' button. Expected result: "3" is displayed with out any error log and exceptions Actual result: "The value of the property"name"is required"" occurs Error logs: A BIRT exception occurred. Plug-in Provider:Eclipse.org Plug-in Name:BIRT Model Plug-in ID:org.eclipse.birt.report.model Version:2.2.0.v20061103-0630 Error Code:Error.PropertyValueException.VALUE_REQUIRED Error Message:The value of the property "name" is required.
Reassign to model team to correct the bug.

When converts data set design to handle, the data set parameter name may be null. This result in exception later.
Fixed.
verified and closed

bug.short_desc: Reduce size of buffers used for CVS decoration calculation

long_desc.thetext:
Version: 3.2.0 Build id: M20060629-1905
Currently CVSDecoratorConfiguration#decorate uses two 80 character buffers to calculate the prefix and suffix of the item being decorated. The default prefix for all items is a single character and the suffix is about 20 odd characters. Would it be possible to change the buffers to 1 character for the prefix and about 32 for the suffix? It isn't much of a saving, but that extra memory is currently just being wasted.
It might even be possible to guess the amount of the buffer needed by using the format string. I developed some code for subclispe that parses the format strind and stores it in an object form so the format doesn't have to be parsed each time an item is decorated. This parsed format string would help speed up the decorator and would be useful for guessing the required buffer size.

I have removed the specification of a size and will just use the default. Given that the prefix and suffix strings are transient and the cost of expanding the string buffer is small (and is done in the background), I don't think it is worth further optimization. If you disagree, you are welcome to reopen this bug.
Verified

bug.short_desc: SWT crashes X server - reproducably

long_desc.thetext:
I am experiencing the following problem:
In Eclipse, I was debugging a Java application and accidentally printing a collection to stdout (instead of just its size). This lead to a huge output to the Eclipse Console view - apparently too big for SWT to handle. This reproducibly crashed the X-server. This is under Ubuntu and Eclipse 3.2.0.
I also tried the IBM JVM instead of the Sun JVM and this still lead to the same problem. Hence, I suspect it's some issue (buffer overflow?) in the native code of SWT. I am not sure if this can be used maliciously, but in any way, it's a little worrying.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 87299 ***

bug.short_desc: vertical scrollbar not properly drawn in properties view
